answers.answer: Ruby, if she has relatives with celiac, have her tested for celiac. It can 'come on' at any time during a person's life and it can produce GI distress that's hard to pinpoint. It may not give true symptoms in some people until it's very advanced and very problematic.It might also be good to have her checked for diabetes.

question: My daughter is 23 and she is intellectually disabled.   For a few years now she complains of pains that go across her midriff area.  Not specifically on one side or the other or in the centre, she describes it as right across, when she shows me she puts her hands right across her middle and around to the back a bit.I think she has a fairly high pain threshold (she gets her eyebrows waxed without wincing!)She probably gets the pains about twice a week and they can last for hours, sometimes a panadol doesn't ease them much.The thing is,  she doesn't have ANY other symptoms to go with the pain.  No nausea or anything.She takes the pill continually for period pain and because she can't handle her periods due to her disability.  So she doesnt get a break from the pill (its been about 4 years non-stop without a break)  She is not sexually active.She also takes zoloft for her OCD and anxiety disorder.She is also overweight (about 130 kgs)   She only leaves the house 3 times a week with her carers  (I live 300kms away from her)I know if I took her to the doctor, all we could say was "She gets pains across the tummy"  theres nothing else we can say, she is very non-specific about her symptoms.  Other than that she is really healthy and hardly ever gets sick.Her grandfather has caeliac disease which came on in his 60's.   Also diabetes on her fathers side which came onto him and his brother in their 40's.She has never been one to go to the toilet until the very last minute.Any clues?Ruby.
title: Strange abdominal pain
